content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Elle présente un problème suffisamment complexe et est intéressante pour les propriétés des nombres.

Yes, good idea. 2 points :
1) I don't understand specifically the link with the vampires...
2) Your solution is improvable : by replacing
for a in range(1,n)  --> for a in range(1000,10000)
you avoid a thousand of useless iteration at each test, and then the if statement become simpler, since we already know that a is a 4-digit number

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Cool clash!
All test cases work, unambiguous statement and medium difficulty.
Perfect !
Seems hard to solve in 15min for someone who isn't into number theory. But good puzzle and fun story :)

Needs some light editing for readability but otherwise a good puzzle, like Allis said. One stumbling block for me was not understanding initially that not only are a and b factors of n, that a x b = n. To me, "factor" just means that it divides evenly into n; it says nothing about its relation to other factors. Put another way, 1 and 2 are factors of 12 but 1 x 2 != 12.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Now this is a puzzle with style! Based on a cool thing from number theory, solid test cases, great names, and just a fun vibe all around.

Really nice contribution!
That makes sense since so many clashes are about listing all factors, and not about pairing them. I introduced the term "fangs" from the literature for clarity, and removed some redundancy.
